I've played a bunch, and I really actually do enjoy the game!
That said, I cant really recommend it right now...
Everyone says "Oh this is a PvP game", and AGS forces you to do PvP for a lot of different things, but when you then dont play amazing at it, or run a build you enjoy but isnt on meta, the community is honestly just toxic. And those same people are the ones that will tell you "why do you want to pve, this is a pvp game".
Like, if you want people to play pvp you kind of have to be okay with people who arent perfect at it being in your 3v3 arena, because AGS put it on the season bingo card, and sometimes you cant get around it if you want to be able to complete it.
Either this is a PvP game, and the community needs to become more inclusive of new players, or it isnt, and AGS needs to stop forcing people who dont really care about PvP but like PvE and the world to do content they dont like.
You cant have it both ways, I dont think.

Beautiful but Broken: A Stunning MMO Undone by Its Own Systems

At first glance, this game is breathtaking. The visual quality is top-tier – environments are richly detailed, and I have to give special praise to the dungeon design. The atmosphere, lighting, and visual storytelling in those areas truly blew me away while exploring the game for the first time. It felt like there was something magical here – something worth investing time in.

And yet, as I reached the later stages of the game, that initial wonder began to fade. What replaced it was something much less enchanting: a system built around grind, RNG, and what feels like a casino-inspired loot loop.

Inventory Hell
Let’s start with the biggest flaw: the inventory system. It's a mess. You spend an absurd amount of time just sorting through endless piles of junk – useless armor, weapons, and trinkets that serve no purpose. There's no satisfying way to sell or discard them. It’s not just clutter; it actively kills momentum and enjoyment. In WoW, even bad loot had a reason to exist. Here, it’s just digital garbage.

Combat and Progression
The combat is actually good – smooth, responsive, and enjoyable. But the progression is bizarrely lopsided. Leveling is way too fast and easy, while gathering professions like mining become a painful, drawn-out grind. It feels like two separate games – one rushing you forward, the other dragging you back.

Disconnected World, Shallow Exploration
Despite the beautiful locations, the world feels oddly disconnected. There's no meaningful interaction with the environment, no real sense of presence. You don’t need to explore, and once you've seen an area, there’s little reason to return. The world is too small, too static. New zones should be arriving yearly, along with a steady flow of new dungeons and raids – not just recycled ones with increased difficulty.

From Immersion to Slot Machines
This is where the real disappointment hits. The game slowly shifts from immersive MMO to something that feels designed around loot crate addiction. The gameplay ends up revolving around opening boxes, hoping for a lucky drop – like a slot machine in a 24/7 convenience store. That kind of design breaks the fantasy, breaks the immersion, and ultimately breaks the game.

Economy in Chaos
The auction house is another weak link. Because of the nonsensical item system, prices are wildly inconsistent. It’s difficult to judge value, and trading becomes more frustrating than rewarding. It’s a symptom of the game’s deeper design issues.

Bright Spots Still Exist
To be fair, there are elements worth celebrating. The voice-acted NPC dialogue during story quests is a huge plus. Hearing characters speak adds a layer of immersion and personality that plain text just can’t deliver – and it genuinely made me care more about the main story, at least at first. More MMOs should do this.

World bosses and live events also shine – for brief moments, you feel part of a living, breathing community. And the musical instruments and group performances? Pure genius. These systems are fun, original, and show a glimpse of the game’s untapped potential.

Conclusion: A Lost Opportunity
This game could have been one of the greats. It had the budget, the engine, the setting. For a while, it looked like it might truly rival the giants of the genre. But over time, poor design choices, inventory frustration, and a shift toward “casino-style” systems have dragged it down.

It’s beautiful, but broken. A haunting reminder of how potential means nothing without vision.

I come back every now and then to see is AGS has rectified all the blunders, the money duping, the dsync and just generally bad decision making throughout the year. now the lack of content for 18 months is clear sign that NW will go into maintenance mode very soon. 

After all that you're wandering why i recommend the game. £60 for 1400~ hours... that's why. Take the game apart into 100 separate puzzle piece of content and systems and its genuinely amazing; crafting, Sound design, simple but fun combat, world design, gearing, MSQ. But put it all together and its a picture of a giant mouldy turd somehow. 

Buy it enjoy the journey, discover what make the game great, then you'll hit the endgame for like 2 days and turn it off. This game is only about the journey because the destination is about as fun as being mugged. 

See you in October for the next update :)

Base game is ok but not my cup of tea after 30ish hours (never gonna click with every game). However, recently a dear friend of mine (who loves the game) told me about the seasonal server. 

Sounded cool so I installed, choose the seasonal server, created a character and enter the world...intro cut scene begins, I hold escape to skip and boom, back to start up screen. Choose my new character, enter the world, intro cut scene begins but this time I wait for the prompt in the bottom corner to tell me to "Hold ESC to Skip).

Bad idea, back to start up screen. "No biggie" I think, choose my character and login knowing I must sit through the intro scene I have watched 15-20 times in previous attempts to find the fun over the last couple years. Cut scene finishes, my character loads in and.....this is when I am told "Your Character is Locked" and to go pound sand until I buy the X-Pac.

Easy decision at this point, uninstalled and a thumbs down from me (pretty sure this is not how you bring players back).

Why not just tell us before we create the character? I would have still uninstalled but no way the negative review would have even entered my mind..

I am perplexed by the hate in the reviews. I've noticed alot of times lately games become 'popular to hate' when they have a launch that is flawed in any way, or even just not the end-all-be-all game to spend every future waking second playing for them personally, they start or create some kind of hate train.

As a traditional fantasy MMORPG format, this is one of the newest and by far the best iterations of that genre. This game has one of the best combat systems ever put in an MMORPG, BY FAR. With active, split second dodging, real hit-boxes where you can jump over and duck under projectiles and swings actually miss if they don't physically touch you. I believe there are character collisions as well, IIRC. All projectiles have to actually be aimed, which adds a HUGELY immersive element to large raids or the fortress defense activity things. For instance, as an archer, you are actually aiming the arrows slightly upward to compensate for gravity's pull, so the arrows fall into the mob of melee fighting going on ahead of you between the enemy NPC melee and your own RAID group. Combat is fast paced, and positioning matters greatly, ESPECIALLY when using a weapon like rapier. Every fraction of a second matters because some of your abilities effectively teleport behind the enemy, but doesn't stun for like 3 seconds like in WOW. You are just using your abilities and positioning to actually physically dodge the enemies attacks. Not getting hit no matter what, and hoping it rolls well, again, like in traditional MMORPGs. The combat in this is much faster paced and way more movement, positioning, and timing involved because you actually have to 'HIT' the enemy, and they you.

The class system is great; you can effectively level every class on one character if you choose, and the same goes for crafting/skills type leveling. 

The music system is bar-none the absolute best. The game practically has Guitar Hero (without the guitar controls, so step mania?) or Rockband just built into the game as a skill to level and progress. And you can do it with your other party members or whomever, and each person plays a different instrument and part of the song.. for like 100s of songs, IIRC.

The builds system is unique and very customizable. Each weapon has a major and minor stat that contributes to it. And you can equip two weapon types to switch between. So, I.E. speccing with high dexterity helps you as a 'major' stat for both bow and spear. But, it also helps by contributing half points to things like Hatchet and Two handed sword as a 'Minor' stat. combine this with magic type weapons, and a talent tree style system, and you get the picture. 

Sorry if some of it is vague, a lot is coming from memory. But I am actually reinstalling the game right now.

One tip: Check the server populations online before you make your character. Currently, in the US, Us West servers are virtually empty compared to the healthy population on Us East. XD

Anyways, if you're looking for a traditional(ish) fantasy MMORPG with great combat and leveling and skills system.... New World is actually my 10/10 favorite.

I’ve only played this game for maybe 100 hours a couple of years ago and then just come back and played another 20 or 30 just now .
I understand that some people have complained that the endgame content is a little lacking but I haven’t really come up against that yet.
What I’ve played I have loved , the game feels really good and looks beautiful the movement is silky smooth and very crisp  the sound is amazing and brings the game to life. Gathering and crafting system is probably the most fun I’ve ever experienced in any MMO.
Monetisation is very fair with no ptw. 
Overall I think New world is probably a better choice for casual gamers than for hardcore gamers who want a no life experience that they can dedicate hours every day to. 
I would say that the game offers great value for money for those who want a beautiful, immersive experience with at least a couple of hundred hours of gameplay. 
Also feel like , if you’re starting the game now , by the time you reach end game there will probably be a whole lot more content available for you to enjoy.

Oh man, the new/returning user experience is absolutely atrociuos. I come back after a year and start a new character on the option it give me for the seasonal server. I create the entire character and the story starts, im not too interested so I see if I hold Esc is will skip the story, but on the bottom right it also says, press Esc to go back. So I hold Esc to skip the story and wouldnt you know it, it stops the story and goes straight back to the main menu.

At this point, I've tried it multiple times, welp, I guess I just cant skip the story. So I sit through the story while on my phone, because I dont care at this point. After 5 min the story ends and my character shows on screen, for just a split second, before it says I "need to purchase the expansion before blah blah blah". So you let me spend all the time to create a character, forced to watch you silly story and after all that BS you finally let me know I need to purchase the expansion before playing that mode?!

LOL that is some of the most ridiculous $%!T i've ever seen. I get that expansions are a thing, let me know when I select the mode, not after i've put time in. That's just a very small example of what I'm sure is absolutely entrenched in this game, absolutely zero respect for the players time. That's the sign of a social experiment, not a game. When you have to FIND the fun, it's all but over.

So far, I don't really understand the hate with this game. Most of the expansion definitely should of been apart of base game but, that's a review of the expansion not the base game. 

Good----
1. Story lines are good shoot most of the side quests are pretty fun too. 
2. You feel strong with good gear and eventually as you level you start weakening out and need to get new stuff which feels balanced and fair. 
3. The zones blend pretty smooth and there's more variety of mobs compared to New World when it was released.
4. The faction system really encourages you to get into pvp BUT it doesn't feel shoved down your throat
5. Buy it once, no monthly sub, no P2W that I've noticed

Bad---
1. Sometimes there's some (minor) connectivity issues.
2. Every time I see someone on a mount I get miffed that in order to ride one (something every other MMO has base game) I need to pay another $30 for
3. While the game is a buy once, play forever style it's frustrating that for things like transmog and other basic stuff they charge for it. The main problem here I think is it costs way too much for something like that. I want my character to look cool but damn if it's going to cost that much I'd rather pay a sub and have it thrown in for free.
4. The setting camp feature is a really neat feature but it's a pita to find one nearby to use.

Overall, 7/10

Devs já deixaram de saber oq estão fazendo com esse jogo faz muito tempo. Um bilionário colocou uma bolsa de dinheiro infinito no colo de incompetentes e deixou eles gerindo um mmo sem supervisão.

Não recomendo.
- Balanceamento porco e preguiçoso.

- Pay2Win: ou você paga pra avançar de forma ainda insatisfatória, ou vai ralar mais que um clt em 6x1 para conseguir equipamentos medíocres.

- Reworks e adições horríveis: mudam totalmente o funcionamento de mecânicas (atributos, perks, etc), do nada, inutilizando completamente sets que você ficou 6 ou mais meses para conseguir deixar minimamente usável.

- Falta de transparência: não avisam de atualizações e nem compartilham os planos, só surgem igual o mestre dos magos, soltam uma bomba inútil e somem. 

- Poucos jogadores: maioria já pulou fora, só ficou quem tem algum transtorno psiquiátrico grave. Maioria dos servidores estão inóspitos, e a gerencia faz questão de tomar escolhas para dividir ainda mais a player base que sobrou. Já é praticamente um jogo singleplayer de mundo aberto. Com o aumento de preço ridículo que eles fazem a cada ano não espere novos jogadores.

- Muito repetitivo: como se já não bastasse poucos jogadores, resultando em tempos de espera gigantes para fechar um time pra uma dungeon ou expedição, a quantidade absurda de vezes que você tem que repetir alguma coisa para avançar (dungeon, coleta, etc) destrói toda a vontade de jogar. É sempre a mesma coisa, nada muda, não tem nada procedural, nenhum incentivo.

- Muitos bots: por ser sempre a mesma coisa, muitos dos jogadores que vc encontrar fazendo algo, na real são bots programados para ficar repetindo ações, e consequentemente te atrapalhando.

- Sistema de report é um lixo: é cheio de hacker e bots, mas os únicos que são banidos serão aqueles que as panelinhas e os streamers fizerem report bomb, ou seja, só é banido aqueles que eles não forem com a cara e que jogam na moralzinha, os hackers e bots saem impunes na maioria das vezes.

- Mal otimizado: roda mal até em maquina high end.

- Cheio de bugs: como se ja não bastasse a otimização horrível sem motivo algum, ainda tem bugs, glitches e exploits à rodo. É tão bizarro, que tinha* comunidades em diversos locais (discord, reddit, telegram, e outros fóruns) que eram* dedicadas a explorar essas falhas pra tirar vantagem e fazer graça. *No passado, pois se restou 1 ou 2 comunidades ativas de algo sobre New World é muita coisa já. Fora os bugs ocasionais que atrapalham sua gameplay, são muitos, e quando corrigem 1 aparecem outros 2.

- Muito caro: paguei uns 50 conto na época, e o jogo sempre foi porco com administração duvidosa, pelo menos tinha muitos jogadores, ainda era um mmo [multiplayer **massivo** online] apesar dos muitos problemas. Hoje ta só o caco, ou nem isso, ta só o pó do caco. Quem pagar o preço atual, ou mais de 100 reais nessa porcaria que seja, pode pegar seu troféu de otário. No valor de 50 ja tava ruim, e agora parece que piorou.

Very fun action combat PvP MMORPG. Loved the open world skirmishes, wars, OPR, 3v3s. Blunderbuss and firestaff are a lot of fun. Gathering is also some of the best in any MMO game. Chopping down trees is so satisfying. The transmog feature addition is also very good, along with the projectile bullet change. Many good changes over the years. Not a big fan of their focus on pumping out boring dungeons, or the PvE in OPR, their Junkyard engine, all the bugs, the massive amount of gold going to territory company owners (although the horizontal gear progression made this less of an issue), and imbalance with bows/muskets. There's a large focus on PvE when it's not that great; very little focus on open world PvP, wars, 3v3s, and OPR which is where this game shines. Devs seem to listen to their players but the shift in focus away from NW at AGS hurt the PC playerbase (especially after the Aeternum console update). Also I think the corruption portals should be more similar to those seen in the game Oblivion! Stopped playing after the game rename patch. Mainly played BB/FS, BB/Hatchet, GS/Hatchet. I think adding friendly fire would be interesting, just to see how it would change the meta for wars.

No entiendo el hate hacia New World. Aunque tuvo un lanzamiento complicado, el juego ha evolucionado muchísimo. A día de hoy, ofrece un mundo visualmente impresionante, con una ambientación única que mezcla fantasía, colonización y mitología de forma muy original. El sistema de recolección, crafteo y profesiones es de los más satisfactorios que he probado en un MMO, y la sensación de progresión es muy gratificante.

Además, el PvP masivo y el control territorial entre compañías siguen siendo de lo más adictivo cuando se juega en grupo. Amazon ha sabido escuchar (aunque tarde) y ha corregido muchos errores del inicio. El nuevo sistema de temporadas, la mejora de las mazmorras, el balance del equipo y los eventos dan una buena razón para volver o seguir disfrutándolo.

Y sobre el precio, mucha gente se queja de que cuesta dinero, pero sinceramente, prefiero esto mil veces antes que un juego lleno de microtransacciones y pay to win disfrazado. Al final, un juego tiene que ser rentable: si no pagas por entrar, te lo van a cobrar por otro lado.

After Guild Wars 2, this is the best MMO for a solo player. Great graphics and excellent optimization. Combat is very satisfying, and hitboxes work perfectly, which makes every fight feel smooth and rewarding. Crafting is also very satisfying. This game doesn’t really have any major downsides if you’re a casual player and not even looking for an MMO, but rather a good RPG.

What I appreciate most is the lack of “Asian-style” influences. Maybe the side quests aren’t too ambitious, but the overall atmosphere of the game is fantastic.

Another big plus is the absence of aggressive microtransactions (even though they do exist). Still, having to pay for a mount as part of a DLC feels a bit over the top. But you can’t have everything. After around 50 hours, I did get a bit bored, but maybe that’s just because I play solo :) Either way, I highly recommend it.

Any downsides? Maybe the world is a bit small.
I’m eagerly waiting for the second part.

TLDR: Fun earlygame but even before reaching the end of Main Story line it becomes very repetitive and boring. Needs more variety when it comes to combat and content.

Story is decent, although has a few dips here and there (IMO first big bad introduction as corrupting cunning force was pretty weak, she seemed like a 100% villain with taunts rather than making valid points). Sidequests range from normal to a bit weird, but almost all are voiced. They do lack variety though, there aren't really any proper puzzles or custom mechanics tied to quests like in some other MMOs.

The world is pretty but looting broken houses for absolutely the same materials gets quite repetitive very fast. The game really would benefits from metas and dynamic world events that some other MMOs have.

Combat is a mixed experience. From one point of view it's very responsive. From another it's just switching between 2 weapons with 3 active skills of out 6 toal + very minor skill customization. Oh and also +1 skill from heartrune. It lacks depth, variety. Feels spammy and by the time I reached Elysian Wilds I got bored with it, even though I started switching ranged weapon between bow and firestaff.
On top of that DPS builds are too squishy. It's not fun when enemy sneezes at you and you lose 50% hp or straight up get oneshot.
Blocking is very hard because of visual spam, it's just impossible to see when enemies attack. And there is no option to turn down/hide ally skill effects, so if you're part of 20-man raid, the screen is a multicolored vomit.

I didn't quite get into endgame content aside from trying some open world elite chest runs and M1 expeditions, but it seems that endgame is mostly raid and mutated expedition grind. There aren't many mutated expeditions and once again they get repetitive fast, while giving barely any useful rewards.

Gearing could be done better. You loot various named upgradeable gear pieces with 600+ GS but in reality when it comes to PvE gear, everyone is running the same 3 perks, because they're strictly better for survivability. At the end of the day, you salvage 99% of gear you loot.

Lançam uma "DLC" pro jogo que adiciona 5 níveis (o que faz muita diferença em um jogo que o nível max sem DLC é 60), montaria (o que ajuda muito para o grind infernal dos recursos), 1 classe (meio fds por mim). Pode parecer pouco, mas isso dá uma vantagem imensa para quem compra DLC em questão de acesso a recursos, itens de níveis mais altos, etc. Com isso, o PVP é desbalanceado para quem tem a DLC (que até onde vi parece que a maioria dos players possuem).
Não só isso, mas essa DLC custa "apenas" 150 reais, sendo inviável para a maioria dos jogadores. Com isso os servers atuais do NW estão vazios.
Pra um jogo que custava 70 reais no lançamento, custar 437 agora é um desserviço tanto para novos jogadores quanto para os antigos (já que afasta os novos).
Dito isso, considero o jogo paytowin, então entre apenas se tiver a grana. Mas mesmo assim não acho que vale a pena pelo grind absurdo que tem para os recursos.
Jogo bom, completo e bonito. Porém, devia ser mais barato para chamar novos jogadores.

New World was one of the first MMOs I truly got into—and for a while, I loved it.
The launch was exciting, the world was beautiful, and the gameplay loop was fresh. For those first few weeks, it really felt like something special. Everyone seemed to be having a great time.

But over time, the magic faded. Player numbers dropped, and the updates felt either too minor or too slow to make a difference. It’s hard to pinpoint exactly where things went wrong—but something definitely did.

Now with Aeternum, it feels more like an attempt to revive something that had so much potential but was never fully realized. I really wanted this to be a long-term MMO home for me. Sadly, it just didn’t stick.

This was the game that was going to change the MMO/RPG scene. Unfortunately like most developers they promise gold and give you turd. 

The foundation of the game was promising, the world looked stunning, the quests where okay to grind, the grind wasn't to quick or to long, the classes, weapons, and armour where good but it quickly shown you had no idea what you was doing . 

The first problem was not enough worlds on servers. You had friend groups who were on all different worlds and servers because they was that full they couldn't get in together. They promised that once more worlds were available you could switch worlds and SERVERS to join friends and told us to keep grinding . We had a friend group of about ten that was all split up and I think half left the game soon as it was announced we couldn't change to be with our friends . 

The ones who kept playing enjoyed the game (despite some of us having to start back at level 0) all the way up to the point of end game. Full story and quests done. The raids were fun but only so much you can do over and over again . 

The main problem was the PVP. Iv always said that for a game to survive long term there has to be a good and fair PvP system for all players, once the main PvE story is done and completed hundreds of raids what then? It's check out PvP or go play a different game.

Now the PvP combat was fun and so was the PvP events but the problem they had was the Territory wars for settlements.
Now settlements gave clans massive bonuses and incomes of gold if they held them so was really important but only the biggest and top clans could compete for these settlements leaving smaller clans having no look in. So the only option to be apart of these wars was to join a big clan right? Wrong, even if you join a clan the leader selects who he wants to fight in the wars so you never get a look in because he picks all his mates and sweats. 

Why not make smaller settlements to be took over that can only be took over by clans with 10 or less people ? Or 20 ? Everyone can have a good PvP experience and enjoy the wars

Bcp de personne disent que le jeu est mauvais. Je pense juste ça dépend de votre profil de gamer et de MMO RPG.

Profil MMO : 
o Casual player (Je n'accroche pas à WoW ou à Lost Ark)
o Full PvE (JcE) (Je n'aime pas le PvP)

Points positifs :
o Les graphismes sont vraiment très bons pour un mmo rpg. Je l'ai notamment comparé à TESO qui pour moi est nettement plus vieux par rapport à NW. Pour WoW la DA est tellement particulière que c'est pas comparable.
o Le système de quête et de leveling sont vraiment bien adapté pour les profils casuals comme moi. On peut atteindre le level max (65) sans groupe, tout peut être fait en solo, même si certains bosses sont compliqués.
o Le stuffing en terme de scaling est bon aussi. On reçoit des items qui nous permettent largement de matcher les dégâts des monstres lorsqu'on évolue de zone au cours de la quête principale.
o Le système d'arme est vraiment stylé. Pas de classe, que des armes qui donnent des compétences et qui permettent d'adopter un style différent d'une arme à une autre sans changer de personnage, ce qui est très agréable.

Points neutres :
o Les métiers sont biens pensés, mais le leveling pour certains est tellement long et lent que lorsqu'on passe à côté de certaines ressources et qu'on ne peut pas les prendre, c'est frustrant mais je trouve que pour le endgame c'est cool.
o Les quêtes annexes sont biens mais sur le début de jeu, ça n'exp rien par rapport à la quête principale ce qui est dommage pour les gens qui aiment faire les quêtes annexes avant la principale. Le ration : bénéfice/temps investi n'est pas rentable sur l'early et c'est dommage

Point négatifs :
o Le fait d'acheter le jeu à 60€, je trouve qu'il les vaut, cependant, les micro-transactions pour les cosmétiques et surtout pour les jetons transmog pour avoir l'apparence d'équipement... Bon ça c'est pas ouf. Si vous voulez avoir un beau perso harmonieux, faut compter rajouter 50-60€ facile.
o L'après-leveling 65 : La transition est pas très fluide parce qu'il n'y a pas de point de repère pour optimiser son stuffing ou de te faire comprendre où aller pour t'optimiser et devenir meilleur pour peut être passer sur du JcJ ou du contenu very endgame qui requière de l'optimisation maximal.
o  Les expéditions (Les donjons) : Je suis sur le monde Ariès et pour trouver une expédition facilement en normal, il faut vraiment se lever tôt. Le jeu n'est pas mort, mais compliqué de trouver si vous n'êtes pas dans une faction ou une "guilde"/communauté.
o Certains bugs un peu relou comme l'apparition de mobs sans barre de vie (donc immortel) qui te lache des moins 500 au level 35, pas ouf ouf.

Conclusion :
Le jeu est cool et je pense vraiment que c'est un très bon jeu. J'ai fait 42h de jeu en 5 jours, ce qui est vraiment pas mal, j'y ai accroché au vu de mon profil de joueur de MMO RPG. Je pense que si vous êtes un hardcore des MMO type Wow, etc. et un gros gros consommateur de contenu very endgame PvE, je ne sais pas si ce jeu s'adresse à vous. Mais si vous êtes comme moi un casu qui aime bien jouer de manière chill et juste passer du bon temps en jouant, le jeu est à mon sens adressé pour vous.

The thing is, I saw some new vids on youtube and was like hell yeah let me revisit New World, you know, Amazon's flagship MMORPG, or as I like to call it, Jeff Bezos’ $500 million Minecraft server for bored spreadsheet enjoyers. If this game is the future of gaming, then grab your loincloth and stone tools, because we’re going back to the Dark Ages. Not the fun, sword-swinging Dark Ages the ones with lice, mud, and dysentery.

This game is less “New World” and more like “Expired Product Left in Bezos’ Garage Since 2018.” You log in, greeted by a loading screen (on my new killer rig with suck yo dack nvmes and shit) that lasts longer than Amazon’s commitment to workers’ rights, and enter a world where every single player is either a tree-chopping automaton or a shirtless gremlin spawn-camping a wolf den for crafting mats. You’re not building a fantasy empire you’re doing unpaid labor in a digital Amazon warehouse.

Fighting is is a mix of circle jerk and pray with all the satisfying impact of hitting a wiffle ball with a wet sock. Somehow, despite this being 2025, swordfighting feels like two mannequins slap-fighting  in a 2004 Dr. Who episode.   PVP boils down to what I call... the dance.   Moving on.
The story, which is like someone asked ChatGPT to write a fantasy plot but trained it exclusively on Amazon Prime TV scripts. You’ve got your usual “ancient evil,” “corrupted magic,” and “you are the chosen one” tropes, but written with all the depth of a Jeff Bezos LinkedIn post. The voice acting is a buffet of accents nobody asked for. One guy sounds like a Narubian pirate that has never seen the ocean, another like he’s doing a low-budget Bridgerton audition on syrup. I half-expected someone to say, “By the light of the Amazon Algorithm, Bezo's protects!”

Oh yeah the algorithms, i mean... auction house.  The game’s economy is a lawless stock market simulator run by dupe fiends who majored in meme coins. Inflation runs wild. A stick costs more than your first car. Gold farming is more lucrative than your actual job. Crafting is a Kafkaesque nightmare requiring 900 bear pelts, three star-metal penile implants, and the blood of Bezos himself to make a Level 3 chair.

The true glory here though, what really makes New World special is its glorious commitment to soulless bloat. Everything takes forever. Walk for 15 minutes, fight a boar, get 2 XP, repeat until you are dead inside. Bruh, I have played F2P Korean MMOs with more forgiving grinds.

This game has a horrible endgame loop and feels like it was developed by a team that has been clueless from the start. It’s hard to tell if the game is supposed to be pvp or pve focused, because both aspects are poorly executed. Other games do each of these far better, so I’m left wondering: why should I even bother with this one?

The only real positive is the graphics, but even that is inconsistent. The environments look great, but the character models are ugly and feel out of place, like they were made by a completely different team. It’s a jarring mismatch that breaks immersion.

Combat is passable. It feels okay for an action-based MMO, but nothing more. Definitely not a standout feature.

To make matters worse, the game is full of bugs. Features often don’t work as intended. Want to try the new event quest? Too bad—your chest chain might bug out, and there’s no fix. This happened to me at least twice, and it's incredibly frustrating.

Overall, this game is a mess. Between the broken systems, unfocused design, and endless technical issues, it’s hard to find a reason to recommend it.

10/10 game New World gives you a continent and says, “Good luck.”

Best parts; 

{1} Open World Exploration and the world building is 10/10. Each biome is unique in quests, animals, enemies, houses, people and the culture. For Example, Brimstone sands is a massive desert territory with scorpions, coyotes, lions, ect. The Brimstone quests all focus on Ancient Egyptian and Roman mythology and lore. If youre not interested in that, here are some other long questlines built around other mythologies and legends; 
Greek Mythology: Greek mythology can be found within the game's lore. including a boss fight with Medusa.
Viking/Norse Mythology: There are Norsemen characters, such as the Rus' Varangians led by Warlord Varik, who play a role in the island's story, connecting to legendary figures.
Arthurian Legends: King Artorius (King Arthur) and the Knights of the Round Table are featured in the lore, adding elements of British and Arthurian mythology. The amount of effort put into making each region feel unique makes this a game you could easily spend hundreds of hours in without even touching PvP or grinding.

{2} Combat in New World: Aeternum is one of the best in the MMO genre. It's fluid, responsive, and actually skill-based a huge breath of fresh air compared to the usual tab-targeting systems in other MMOs. You have to dodge, aim, block, and time your attacks, which gives every fight a more action RPG feel. Whether you’re swinging a greatsword, firing a musket, or casting void magic, every weapon feels weighty and distinct. It feels like playing an action RPG in a MMORPG setting. There is also a lot of variety with the weapon choices and skills so you can play any way you want. 

{3} PVE PVE PVE PVE I lowkey hated pvp in any MMO before new world and other MMOs put more effort into PVP then unique enemies. enemies in Mew World behave differently depending on faction undead enemies fight very differently than corrupted knights or ancient constructs. Boss fights often require real strategy and positioning, especially in expeditions (dungeons) or elite zones. And in PvP? The combat system makes 1v1s and group battles feel intense, fast-paced, and fair (as long as your build isn’t completely busted, anyway) but PVP is fun asf and not forced theres a Free For All zone with dabloons you collect if you die you lose them, if you get out you keep them. FFA is fun, Outpost Rush is super fun and they added a new map for it. PVE content is amazing theres tons of expeditions, dungeons, elite raids Weekly invasions which are fucking amazing 20 people in a discord VC with someone giving everyone directions on where to go. there is a daily refresh for soul trials so you can do daily solo boss fights for unique rewards. and WEEKLY rotation for Mutated dungeons, and massive world events like Myrk, Siren, Well, and World Tours. 


{4}The trade skills in New World: Aeternum are a full game on their own. This isn’t your typical MMO crafting where you just click “craft” and walk away. Every profession from gathering to refining to crafting has real depth and impact on your character and the game world. There are 17 different trade skills split across gathering, refining, and crafting, and each one has its own leveling path, perks, and unique gameplay loops.
Gathering includes mining, logging, harvesting, skinning, and fishing. Each resource node is placed in the open world, and they don’t just sit in plain sight.
Refining lets you process those raw materials into usable components like turning iron into steel or rawhide into rugged leather. These aren’t throwaway skills either; mastering refining improves efficiency and quality, unlocking rare materials and bonuses.
Crafting is where it all comes together. Whether you're making gear (weapons, armor), consumables (potions, food), or furniture for housing, crafting in New World feels rewarding. There’s a ton of customization, with stats, perks, and even luck modifiers influencing the quality of what you make.
There is also a skill called Music which is what made me get the game originally. Many different instruments to play and tons of songs to play that give buffs to your group. Player Economy, Goated Af this one goes hand in hand with trade skills, anything you craft or even powerful loot you find in a dungeon can be sold on the market or traded between players for Gold or Other items, makes the world feel soooo alive and I truly love this feature.

{5} Fashion in this game is great there is an amazing transmog system and Ive spent hours making new outfits. Any armor you pick up saves that style as a transmogable piece to any armor youre wearing, are you wearing light armor but wanna look like youre in full plate armor to bamboozle players in PvP? easy and you can get transmog tokens in the battle pass or just buy them. 

Theres much more I could say but I'll leave it at this; There’s much more I could say, but I’ll leave it at this: New World: Aeternum is one of the most underrated MMOs out there right now and it deserves your time.

I came back to the game after a few years. I bought the DLC because I figured a lot had changed and it was worth playing again. A new season has started, and a hardcore server is about to launch in the coming days. It’s a good time to give it a try. There’s a season pass with an option to buy premium access. That’s fine—many games have something like that. The free rewards are decent too. There’s a new storyline, modified areas, and added mechanics. I got really into it while playing on a fresh start server. There are lots of players. Finally, the HC seasonal server is launching… Everything looks great. I really like the accelerated leveling and item acquisition system.

Hardcore mode means that if your character dies, you can still keep playing, but you lose the ability to earn the seasonal reward given only to those who survive. That’s awesome—a real challenge, and a very difficult one at that.

If your character dies, you still have a chance to earn a different reward, but you have to focus on PvP and defeat players who haven’t died even once. To help with this, you get bonus stats after each death, making the task a bit easier. It’s an interesting and very engaging system that encourages open-world PvP.

And here’s where my enthusiasm ends. Even though I paid a lot of money for the game, in order to unlock rewards from the main seasonal system, I have to buy the premium pass. Without it, there’s no point in even trying to avoid death, because it won’t get you anything. I’m simply excluded from the fun. It’s a low blow and a moral downfall for the game’s developers.

I really tried to give New World: Aeternum a fair shot, but it’s just not worth it.

This game is not new-player friendly at all. From the moment you step into Aeternum, you're met with confusing systems, poor onboarding, and a community that seems more interested in flaming newbies than helping them. There's no guidance, no welcoming atmosphere—just a constant uphill battle to understand the basics while getting mocked in chat.

The overall vibe is toxic. Whether it’s in global chat, PvP zones, or even some group content, people are constantly rude, dismissive, or flat-out aggressive. It feels like if you didn’t play since launch day, you’re already the enemy.

Visually, the game looks great, and the combat can be fun at times—but none of that matters if the experience makes you feel unwelcome and frustrated.

If you're looking for a game to enjoy casually or as a newcomer, this is NOT it.

💬 "Come for the views, stay for the wars."

After almost 100 hours in Aeternum, here’s my honest take:

👍 What I Liked:

    Stunning visuals. The world is gorgeous. Forests, ruins, sunsets—this game is pure eye candy.

    Combat feels great. No tab-targeting here—every dodge, block, and swing matters. Very action-oriented.

    Territory wars & PvP. Join a faction, fight for land, and actually influence the game world. Super addictive.

    Crafting is satisfying. You can literally make a living off crafting and gathering. Everything you do matters.

    Exploration is rewarding. Secret spots, rare resources, cool lore—it's easy to get lost (in a good way).

🤔 What Could Be Better:

    Some bugs and balance issues, though they’ve been improving with regular updates.

    PvE content is a bit repetitive early on, but endgame expeditions and seasonal content help a lot.

🔥 Final Verdict:

If you enjoy immersive worlds, skill-based combat, and building your own story in an ever-changing sandbox, New World is worth diving into. It’s not perfect, but it’s growing into something really special.

✅ Recommended

permanent ban - 2025/5/29
Dear New World Support Team,

I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to respectfully appeal the recent permanent ban on my Aeternum account,
which was issued due to an alleged use of a known cheat program. I take both the integrity of my gameplay and the health of the Aeternum community very seriously,
and I can assure you that I have never installed, run, or otherwise used any third-party software to gain an unfair advantage.

On the day I received the ban notification 2025/5/29,
I was actively engaged in completing the main story quests and exploring New World as I have faithfully done for over 1,700 hours of gameplay.
My commitment to the game and its community has always been to play honestly and respectfully,
and I would never take actions that could damage my account or harm other players’ experiences. The sudden ban for my second character was therefore both surprising and distressing,
as I have invested significant time and passion into this world.

I kindly request that you review my case and the relevant log files to verify the absence of any unauthorized software on my account.
If there is any further information I can provide to facilitate your investigation,
please let me know.
I greatly value New World and would be deeply grateful for the opportunity to continue playing and contributing to the community under a fair and transparent review process.

Thank you for your time and understanding. I look forward to your response.

tl;dr: It's worth the price and I've enjoyed my 370hrs in-game, but the game leaves you wanting more, which it unfortunately cannot give. Keep that in mind.

It's an MMORPG that always draws me back from time to time, mainly because of its atmosphere, its sound design, its enjoyable combat and the memorable interactions I've had with other players throughout my several play-throughs. Though,  it's a pity that the devs are trying to mend the game into some theme park MMORPG with endless boring quests, whilst spending resources on voice-acted dialogue and cut scenes. That choice alone makes progressing in this game feel like a big chore.  That's not what makes the game great. I remember the game not because of some main story character or an event, I remember it for the times people arranged town-long "human centipedes", the open world ganking with friends and  group and guild pvps, sieges and generally global chat banter. I hate seeing MMORPGs where the devs are trying to make the stories, not the players themselves as it should be in an MMORPG.

This game had (or maybe still has) so much potential, but it's just being over sighted and wasted.

P.S. I hope I won't have to bear seeing Gallahad's hideous character model ever again.

New World: Potencial desaprovechado por decisiones cuestionables

New World podría haber sido uno de los mejores MMORPG de esta generación. Tiene una base sólida, un mundo hermoso y mecánicas con mucho potencial. Pero lamentablemente, sus decisiones han torpedeado gran parte de lo que lo hacía especial.

Añadir monturas como contenido de pago (DLC) en lugar de incluirlas de base es ya una señal preocupante, pero lo más grave es subir el nivel máximo de 60 a 65 y bloquear ese progreso tras una expansión de pago. En un juego que ya cuesta 40€, esto crea una desventaja directa para quienes no puedan o no quieran pagar, especialmente en PvP.

Llamarlo Pay to Win no es una exageración: lo es, por definición. Y quienes lo defienden, ya sea por ignorancia o conveniencia, están ayudando a normalizar prácticas dañinas para toda la comunidad.

Además, la falta de contenido nuevo no le ha ayudado tampoco. Una lástima. Tenía todo para triunfar. Pero así, no. No con estas decisiones. Y desde el cariño que tuve por este mundo... me despido.

Adiós New World, un gran juego con potencial increíble pero gestionado de forma lamentable.

New World: Aeternum is a visually stunning game that offers a blend of crafting, gathering, and combat. The game's unique atmosphere and stunning landscapes make it a captivating experience. Players can explore lush forests, clear rivers, and ancient ruins, each with its own unique vibe. The gameplay is smooth and action-oriented, making each encounter feel dynamic. Players can easily pick up skills and abilities, but there's still room for character development. The social aspect is appreciated, as teaming up with friends or strangers for quests and battles adds an extra layer of fun. However, server queues can be frustrating during peak times. The crafting system is another highlight, as gathering resources and creating gear keeps players engaged. Leveling up skills provides a sense of progression. Despite its challenges, New World: Aeternum is an enjoyable journey for exploration and a mix of RPG elements. However, players should be prepared for a bit of a wait to get in.

Ich habe wirklich das Gefühl, dass die meisten negativen Bewertungen von Spielern kommen, die das Spiel entweder gar nicht, oder nur teilweise gespielt haben. Ich veröffentliche eher selten bis gar keine Bewertungen, aber dieses Spiel hat es verdient, dass man sich dafür ausspricht. Voll vertonte Questen, eine atemberaubend schöne Grafik mit wunderschönen unterschiedlichen Gebieten und Vegetationen, ein absolut zugängliches Handwerkssystem, das sogar ich als Craftingmuffel gut und ansprechend finde, und (ganz wichtig) die FREIE Wahl, tun zu dürfen, worauf man gerade Lust hat, während nichts davon sinnlos ist, weil alles gut belohnt wird. Auch als Solo-Spieler hat man die Möglichkeit, sich gute und starke Ausrüstung zu erspielen, ganz ohne, dass man Echtgeld ausgeben oder Raids laufen muss. Jede Spielweise, jede spielerische Vorliebe kommt in NWA auf seine Kosten. 

Darüber hinaus ist das Kampfsystem ansprechend und doch keine Raketenwissenschaft. Es gibt jede Menge Gegner, die es in sich haben, was zu einem anspruchsvollen Schwierigkeitsgrad führt, der durchaus meisterbar ist und dennoch ein gutes Gefühl zurücklässt. 

Der Open World Gruppencontent, bei dem sich Spieler einfach spontan finden, so dass man auch ohne Gildenzwang und PvP das Gefühl erhält, Teil einer lebendigen Welt zu sein, rundet das Ganze ab. Und nicht zuletzt das sehr ansprechendes Housingsystem, das nicht so heftig einschränkt wie andere Spiele. Hinzu kommen all die guten Quality of Life Elemente, die mich als neue Spielerin sofort abgeholt haben. Ich habe noch nie ein Spiel erlebt, das mir gleich zu Beginn so viel Lagermöglichkeiten gibt oder mich recht schnell mit ausreichend Währung versorgt, egal ob es nun Gold oder Azoth ist. Danke an die Entwickler, dass sie sich schlussendlich so viel Mühe gaben, denn zu Beginn von New World war ich leider gar kein Fan. Das hat sich mit Aeternum vollkommen geändert. 

Mein Fazit ist, wer zögert, weil es immer noch negative Bewertungen gibt, sollte sich bitte einfach selbst ein Bild machen. Das Spiel hat unglaubliches Potential. Und mal ehrlich, in welchem Spiel ist nicht mal ein NPC verbugt? Daran eine Bewertung festzumachen, ist für mich ziemlich albern.

I’ve got over 4,000 hours in New World: Aeternum, so I’ve been through it all—leveling, grinding, crafting, gearing up, and tackling pretty much every bit of content the game throws at you. And for the most part? It’s a blast. Learning expedition mechanics, pushing into raid content, upgrading gear, leveling weapons—that’s the good stuff. It’s rewarding, it’s challenging, and it’s why I kept coming back for thousands of hours.

The problem? Once you've done all that, there’s not much else to keep you going. Chest runs—aka joining a zerg to loot the same boxes every 24 hours—are straight-up boring. It’s the least engaging form of endgame, and unfortunately, it's one of the few repeatable things left once you're geared out. The game nails a lot of its core systems but really falls short when it comes to variety in late-game content.

Don’t get me wrong—New World is still 100% worth playing. If you’re into PvE, combat depth, or just love the grind, you’ll easily get hundreds or even thousands of hours out of it like I did. But once you hit the ceiling, you’ll definitely start wishing for more meaningful stuff to do on a daily basis.

TL;DR:
Amazing combat and PvE progression keep you hooked for ages, but the endgame could use more variety beyond chest zerging.

Amazon Games’ New World launched in 2021 with ambition the size of Aeternum’s sprawling wilderness—and baggage just as heavy. What began as a PvP-focused survival sandbox evolved awkwardly into a full-fledged MMO, then struggled under the weight of inconsistent updates, endgame grind, and a bleeding player base.

Now, with New World: Aeternum, Amazon isn’t just trying to patch holes—they’re rebuilding the ship and inviting console players aboard. And while it’s not a flawless rebirth, it’s the most compelling version of New World to date.

The fictional island of Aeternum has always been New World's greatest strength: a hauntingly beautiful, cursed paradise filled with ancient ruins, corrupted creatures, and factions vying for control. Aeternum doubles down on that promise with a more focused narrative structure, voiced dialogue, and expanded lore.

The new story content introduces stronger characters, better pacing, and a sense of purpose that was missing at launch. You still gather resources and level up, but now you’re not just grinding—you’re adventuring.

Combat in Aeternum remains action-oriented—think dodge rolls, timed blocks, and skill-based strikes—but feels significantly more polished. The addition of target locking, improved animation feedback, and controller support make it feel less clunky and more deliberate.

The weapon system (you equip two, switching between them) continues to offer strong build diversity, and classless progression is still a major selling point. Want to be a heavy-armored mage who lobs ice storms while swinging a greatsword? You can.

The PvE content has seen noticeable improvements, and PvP remains an intense affair—especially in large-scale faction wars, which are now more stable and fun to participate in.

Aeternum preserves New World’s deep and rewarding crafting system. Nearly everything you wear, use, or sell can be player-made, and gathering professions feel meaningfully integrated into the world.

Base-building in the form of housing gets expanded utility, offering more than just cosmetic flair—adding real bonuses and customization, especially for solo players. If you like life-sim elements baked into your MMO, this is where Aeternum shines brightest.

With its launch on Xbox Series X|S and PlayStation 5, New World: Aeternum introduces a revamped UI, controller support, and full cross-play. It runs well on console hardware, thanks to engine improvements and streamlined interfaces.

For new players, the onboarding experience is vastly improved. You’re no longer dumped into an overwhelming world without direction. Now, the game guides you with story missions, tooltips, and better pacing.

Aeternum has done a lot right, but it still inherits some of its predecessor’s grindy DNA. Mid-to-late game content can feel repetitive, and while gear progression is smoother, it still requires commitment. Some systems—like territory control—remain complex and time-consuming for casual players.

And while cross-play is a great step forward, the game doesn’t quite bridge the gap between casual MMO fans and hardcore min-maxers. It walks the line—but not without stumbles.

New World: Aeternum is less a sequel and more a soft reboot, but it earns the right to ask for your attention again. The game is more focused, more fun, and far more complete than it’s ever been. It doesn’t reinvent the MMO genre, but it confidently reclaims its place within it—this time with sharper tools and a broader reach.

Whether you’re a returning player or stepping into Aeternum for the first time, there’s finally a compelling reason to make this world your own.

Best For: Fans of action MMOs, crafting-heavy progression, and immersive open worlds

When New World came out the game was very bland. The exploration was great, but the quests were all the same. However it was fun because you learned about all the systems in the game as you went along and wanted to know what was around every corner. But now 3 years later? It's an entirely different game. And not in a good way. The world is so vastly different than at launch I really know nothing about this world. The main cities are cluttered and hard to follow. The enemies you fight that used to offer some level of difficulty and enjoyable gameplay are now super easy to kill and offer no challenge (very diablo esc) and ALL of the fast travel areas I had before are reset so I have to rediscover the ENTIRE world to travel to cities I already discovered. Realistically it feels as though all of my efforts were wiped away and now I have to start from scratch. Also the fun systems I enjoyed like having an ammo limit and NEEDING food are now irrelevant systems in the game. It just lost all of its appeal. All they needed was better quests and more than 2k players per server, but no, reinvent the wheel. smh. Good game wasted. Thanks Amazon.

What starts out as a decent and refreshing MMO gradually becomes an increasingly frustrating experience. The visuals are great and overall gameplay and combat are solid. The experience of getting to max level is pretty pleasant but once you hit max the experience quickly becomes a boring and relentless grind. Gear is centered around perks and max level gear will have 3 randomly assigned. Your job is to grind as much content as possible in the hopes of finding gear with the perfect combination of perks needed, I imagine several hundred hours would be required to get a full set. Its possible, but prohibitively expensive, to influence one of the perks when upgrading gear. Getting gear with all 3 desired is a very rare occurrence.

Alternatively you might decide to craft gear instead. With crafting you can use randomly dropped items to influence one of the perks, slightly reducing the random chance of getting the gear you need. However, before you're able to craft max level gear you need to max out crafting. Very few people actually accomplish this because the amount of materials needed for levelling are absolutely staggering. To give an idea of just how much grinding is required you will need roughly 850,000 (yes, eight-hundred and fifty thousand) leather alone to level just armouring. With getting between 15-40 resources per node, you'll be skinning, mining, logging, harvesting for several weeks to get just one of the 7 crafting professions maxed out. If that wasn't bad enough the already limited resource nodes scattered throughout the world are often preyed upon by an army of bots and other players masochistic enough to attempt the humiliating grind to max crafting level.

PvP is equally grindy and often completely baffling. Balance is a foreign concept in NW with seemingly minor changes uprooting well established class/builds rendering the current gear grind meaningless in one fell swoop. Some classes are absolutely useless in PvP altogether. Perks again play a major role in being successful in PvP, more so than with PvE. What perks you actually need is a mystery for the average player, the game gives no hint whatsoever as to what might make you survive just a few hits from veteran players. Unleashing your strongest attacks will often barely register on some players and devastate others. Although gear score is normalised for PvP the difference in having perfect gear perks and not is colossal. Unless you're prepared to dedicate your entire existence to min/maxing gear, I'd give the PvP a miss.

The final source of frustration is the prevalence of bugs that just should not be there. The game has been live for over 3 years and still suffers from embarrassingly simple but ultimately annoying glitches. Very often the map might not display everything correctly; the compass (no minimap here) frequently fails to register points of interest or gathering nodes nearby; UI elements get stuck on-screen; sudden crashes to desktop when logging in or an inexplicable failure to connect to the servers unless you do a reboot of your computer and router are common occurrences. Every new update will introduce new and exotic bugs to the experience.

I honestly can't recommend NW to anyone looking for their next long term MMO. If you get it cheap you might enjoy it for the 2-3 weeks before the frustration kicks in but don't expect to stay here long!

I was permanently banned for no reason after reinstalling the game. I hadn’t played in a long time and wanted to check it out again — only to find out I was banned without any warning.

The appeal system gives you one chance, and even that is handled by a bot with a copy-paste rejection. After that, there is no way to reach a human, and customer support refuses to help, always redirecting to the same broken portal.

I have never used cheats or third-party tools, and my account was clean. Yet I was flagged by Easy Anti-Cheat for nothing. No explanation. No review. No justice.

This game punishes loyal players and offers no proper support. Be careful if you're considering spending money on it — you might lose your access overnight and nobody will help you.

Se você está procurando um jogo com uma boa narrativa e liberdade de escolha, este título é altamente recomendado. Ele oferece versatilidade para seguir a história principal, se aprofundar em missões secundárias ou simplesmente explorar o mundo no seu próprio ritmo.
O jogo também brilha no aspecto social — é excelente para jogar com amigos, conhecer novas pessoas ou até mesmo curtir uma aventura solo. A sensação de descoberta e progresso é constante.
O único ponto negativo são os preços das DLCs, que podem pesar um pouco no bolso, especialmente se você quiser acessar todo o conteúdo extra.

Aktuell habe ich rund 260 Spielstunden auf dem Konto. Davon entfielen etwa 140 Stunden direkt auf die Zeit rund um den Release. Schon damals hat sich abgezeichnet, dass dieses Spiel etwas Besonderes für mich werden könnte.

In dieser Anfangszeit habe ich mich komplett auf einen Charakter konzentriert und mit ihm sogar die „Schwefelsandwüste“ durchquert. Doch als ich schließlich im sogenannten Endgame angekommen war, musste ich feststellen: Es gab nicht viel zu tun. Die Inhalte waren damals eher mau, und so verschwand New World für mich erst einmal in der staubigen Ecke meiner Steam-Bibliothek.

Und dort blieb es – ganze zwei Jahre lang.

In der Zwischenzeit widmete ich mich anderen Spielen: World of Warcraft, Forza Horizon und Co. Doch New World hatte ich nie ganz aus dem Blick verloren. Die Faszination blieb irgendwo tief im Hinterkopf erhalten.

Als sich dann in WoW mal wieder die altbekannte Content-Flaute einschlich – und mir persönlich das neue Gebiet, die Goblin-Hauptstadt Lorenhall, auch überhaupt nicht zusagte – machte ich mich erneut auf die Suche nach einem Spiel, das mich wirklich packen konnte. Doch trotz des riesigen Spieleangebots zündete nichts so richtig. Ich probierte mal hier, mal dort, aber der Funke sprang nicht über.

Beim ziellosen Durchstöbern meiner Steam-Bibliothek entdeckte ich plötzlich diesen vergessenen Diamanten wieder – New World. Mit der bald erscheinenden Saison 8 dachte ich mir: "Warum eigentlich nicht? Probier's doch einfach noch mal aus."

Oh Junge – was für eine gute Entscheidung das war.

Ruckzuck war ein neuer Charakter erstellt, und los ging's. Anfangs war ich etwas überrascht von den Archetypen, aber schnell merkte ich, dass sich am grundlegenden Spielprinzip nichts geändert hatte: Waffe leveln, Builds optimieren – alles ganz ohne nerviges Klassensystem. Und genau das liebe ich an diesem Spiel.

Optisch hat sich kaum etwas verändert – aber das ist gar nicht schlimm, denn New World sieht nach wie vor absolut fantastisch aus. Die Welt ist wunderschön gestaltet, die Soundkulisse wirkt lebendig und authentisch, und der Soundtrack? Weltklasse. So sehr, dass ich mir die Musik teilweise sogar auf langen Autofahrten oder beim Radfahren gönne. 😄

Die Hauptstory rund um Artorius und Isabella wurde zwar teilweise nachträglich eingeführt, aber das merkt man kaum – vieles wurde so sauber integriert, dass sich die Geschichte rund und stimmig anfühlt.

Das Kampfsystem ist für mich nach wie vor eines der besten im Genre – wenn nicht sogar das beste. Es ist nicht so überladen und komplex wie bei Black Desert, kein Click-Targeting wie in WoW und auch nicht so – entschuldigt den Ausdruck – „schwammig“ wie in ESO. Es fühlt sich einfach direkt, dynamisch und präzise an.

Was New World für mich so besonders macht, ist die Freiheit, die es mir gibt: Ich kann stundenlang Holz hacken, Tiere häuten, nach Erzen suchen, Berufe leveln, Ruf farmen, mein Haus dekorieren, Expeditionen bestreiten oder mich ganz der Story widmen. Es gibt immer etwas zu tun – und das fühlt sich nie wie Arbeit an, sondern wie ein Teil eines großen Abenteuers.

Die Story selbst ist komplett vertont, stimmungsvoll und macht Spaß. Sie ist gut spielbar, ohne dass man das Gefühl hat, man müsste sich durch endlose Texte quälen.

Ja, die Quests sind – wie in fast jedem MMO – oft nach dem bekannten Muster gestrickt: "Hilf dieser Person", "Töte X Monster", "Sammle Y Kräuter" oder "Bringe dies von A nach B". Aber das stört mich gar nicht. Denn Aeternum ist teilweise so liebevoll und atmosphärisch gestaltet, dass man sich gerne einfach treiben lässt – und dabei fast vergisst, was man ursprünglich vorhatte.


Fazit:
New World ist für mich wie ein guter Wein: Es musste etwas reifen, aber jetzt ist es genau richtig. Wer Lust auf ein immersives, wunderschönes MMO mit tollem Kampfsystem und vielen Möglichkeiten hat, sollte dem Spiel (wieder) eine Chance geben. Es lohnt sich – wirklich!

P.S.:
Lasst euch den Spielspaß nicht von irgendwelchen Miesepetern oder frustrierenden Erlebnissen in Expeditionen oder Raubzügen vermiesen. Jeder Rückschlag ist auch eine Lektion – und mit jeder neuen Erfahrung werdet ihr besser. Bleibt dran, bleibt entspannt und vor allem: Habt Spaß! Denn ein MMO ist genau das, was man selbst daraus macht. 😊

I played New World when it first came out.. and soon lost interest cos the quests lacked depth (or much effort, other than a lot of running). I came back a couple of weeks ago and have already clocked up 50 hours. It is so much better. The quests & main story are much better scripted and planned out, the plot makes more sense,, the cut scenes are good. There is soooo much to do and the world is gorgeous. The world rewards exploring (which is my favourite way to play). Mmm; in short, I'm really enjoying it :-)
Yeah, some people are toxic (I have a theory trolls worry that if they stop typing, they'll instantly cease to exist), but you can filter out most of their noise using the social settings. I find that most people just leave you alone to play your way. There are group players and loads of solo players. The wide range of character build options are a bit overwhelming for my ancient brain but there's loads of advice online to help you with that.
Playing this through slowly really does make this game shine. When you aren't trying to rush or min max everything it really is a great game.

This game was great at launch. 
It's not really worth playing in it's current state.
Seems like there is only a bare bones team up keeping the game. 
Quality of life updates just aren't happening quick enough & it seems like the devs have put their attention elsewhere.

Queue times for dungeons/raids/outpost rush are insane so you can't farm any of the items from those.

The combat & weapons are amazing. Questing is fun. Crafting/farming materials is good (it use to be way more of a grind to craft, some high level crafting items are still way too expensive).

This was the type of game you really had to have played at launch as this game heavily relies on player numbers on your server.

They are doing themselves a disservice by not making any consistent social media content to bring in new players.
They only ever advertise new but uninteresting content updates.

It might be worth it for you to get this game on sale & level up a character. 
It just really falls off after that.

👍 [b] Pros: [/b]

[u] Fun and Fast-Paced Combat [/u]
The fighting system is smooth and exciting. You can easily switch between weapons and skills, which keeps battles fun and varied. It feels more like an action game than a typical MMO, and that’s a good thing.

[u] Crafting Feels Meaningful [/u]
If you enjoy gathering materials and making things, you’ll love this. Whether it’s cooking, blacksmithing, or woodcutting, crafting is well-designed and makes you feel like you’re progressing even outside of battle.

[u] Beautiful and Immersive World [/u]
The game looks stunning. From glowing forests to misty ruins, the world feels alive and is a joy to explore. It’s easy to get lost in the scenery—in a good way.

👎 [b] Cons: [/b]

[u] Low Player Population [/u]
Servers can feel pretty empty at times. It’s harder to find groups for certain content, and towns can feel a bit like ghost towns. This affects how social and active the game feels.

[u] Endgame Feels a Bit Repetitive [/u]
The early parts of the game are great, but once you hit the high levels, there isn’t as much to do. The endgame content doesn’t have the same excitement and can start to feel a bit samey.

[u] Not Easy for New Players [/u]
Group content can be tough for newcomers. Many experienced players assume you already know the mechanics, so if you're new, you might feel lost or left behind in high-level activities.

New World: Aeternum — это амбициозный проект от Amazon Games, который был обещан как революционная MMORPG с уникальной механикой и захватывающим миром. Однако, несмотря на свои сильные стороны, игра сталкивается с множеством проблем, которые не позволяют ей стать тем, что она могла бы быть.

Положительные моменты:

Мир и атмосфера. Aeternum — красивый и разнообразный мир. В нем есть все для того, чтобы быть увлекательным: густые леса, величественные горы, заброшенные города и таинственные руины. Все это создает отличную атмосферу для исследования.

Боевая система. Система боевых действий в New World достаточно динамична и интересна, особенно для игроков, которые любят участвовать в реальных сражениях. Нет классов, и система навыков позволяет игрокам развивать персонажа в разных направлениях.

Множество активностей. Игра предлагает разнообразные способы взаимодействия с миром: от PvE до PvP, крафт, добыча ресурсов и строительство. Есть чем заняться для каждого типа игроков.

Отрицательные моменты:

Технические проблемы и баги. На старте игра столкнулась с массой технических проблем, включая падения фреймов, ошибки в квестах, и проблемы с серверами. Многие из них были исправлены с момента релиза, но все равно время от времени встречаются баги, которые могут повлиять на игровой процесс.

Однообразие контента. Хотя мир большой и красивый, к сожалению, геймплей может стать довольно однообразным. После нескольких часов игры, квесты и активности начинают повторяться, что делает игру менее увлекательной на долгосрочной перспективе.

Гринд и экономика. New World требует большого количества времени на прокачку и крафт, что иногда превращает игру в настоящий гринд. Экономика в игре также иногда вызывает вопросы — рынок нестабилен, и многие элементы могут быть переработаны.

PvP-система. Хотя концепция PvP-сражений и войн интересна, она часто сводится к проблемам с балансом. Бои бывают не всегда сбалансированными, а механики могут быть не столь глубокими, как хотелось бы.

Прогрессия персонажа. Прокачка персонажа не ощущается такой значимой, как в других MMORPG. Это, возможно, связано с отсутствием классов, что делает развитие персонажа немного плоским. Также система умений не всегда позволяет почувствовать реальный прогресс.

Заключение:

New World: Aeternum — игра с огромным потенциалом, но она еще не достигла идеала. Проблемы с багами, однообразие контента и слабая прогрессия персонажа могут оттолкнуть часть игроков. Если вы любите красивые миры и исследования, эта игра может быть интересной, но если вам важна глубина и инновации в игровом процессе, возможно, стоит подождать еще несколько обновлений, прежде чем вернуться в Aeternum.

The game has a unique combat system that makes it very different from any other MMO on the market. If you want to try an MMO with a unique action combat, a beautiful art direction, and amazing music, you must try this game.

Of course, it has some problems, especially because it is a new MMO, so don't expect to spend 1,000 hours into the game without feeling bored or frustated at some point because there's nothing to do, but for the current price (especially because there's no monthly sub), it is totally worth it, at least in my opinion.

I played this game once when it first came out and it was so broken. I stopped playing for years. 
Now I am a returning player and honestly, I do like the game. I like the story, the npcs are quite unique and have distinct voices and stories.
Someone once told me if you like RuneScape, WOW, and rust. You’ll like this game. I love leveling up my character and all the skills and trades. 

However, every update breaks something (what game doesn’t have that problem). The game is kind of dead. Yeah there’s like 6k players online at any given moment- but the game isn’t very new player friendly, there’s hardly anyone who will let you join raids for better gear. 
Since it’s hard on new players it can feel pay to win when people pay to get gear, pay others to carry them through dungeons etc. 
Since it’s difficult to find people to join you on raids, it’s hard to get better gear, there’s also “elite” quest lines which basically require 5 people to complete. Good luck asking random people online for help. 
It seems like the game is gearing toward PVP heavily. 
The people in chat are absolutely wild. I mean, I’ve played a lot of different types of games but NW is wild.

I played New world on release and it was fun but ultimately empty with no end game and barely a mid game and the levelling was painfully slow.

A friend recently convinced me to come back and try it again. I came in with little to no expectations and was surprised.

The same fun fluid combat and crafting is all still there, the levelling has been sped up hugely, the game looks to have an end game now (although far less than a game of its age should).

HOWEVER hiding mounts behind a DLC paywall is scummy and without the DLC the end game still looks to be the same vapid lifeless mess. It also seems to get new content at what seems to be a glacial pace, and with the Aeturnum revamps seeming to have little effect on the player base I doubt that will change.

Do i recommend you buy New World? honestly only if u have friends to play with.

But for the 1 million people that have it on steam since release, honestly it is far better than it once was and well worth a shot again.

I have probably received as much enjoyment as I will get from this game. The game is quite immersive, from background music, to atmospheric sounds and the visuals of the environments. The real time action combat, while overly simple, does feel like every hit is making an impact. This is a negative review time for the parts that aren't so great. Character models are clunky and weird looking, the progress through the main story line is pretty generic, the itemization is too simplistic, crafting starts feeling good then turns into a massive grind. The resource nodes for say mining or gathering, have long cool downs the higher the tier and are public, you can go hours and barely gather any resources. It's been almost 2 years since the game has had a new weapon type. Due to having the gear work for both PvP and PvE, that stat effect numbers are pretty tiny, sometimes barely noticeable. Every update is rough, something almost always breaks, or the content is spread out over a couple of weeks, there's always additional monetization putting up a barrier for something that is often free in most games. Last but not least, Aeternum was advertised as being for solo players or group play. Most of the content at end game can't be soloed, and the best gear is locked behind group play. The game has had good potential since release, but that's all it has ever had.

As a day-one player of New World, Amazon’s ambitious MMORPG, I can confidently say the game has undergone a dramatic transformation since its rocky launch in September 2021. Back then, it was a visually stunning but flawed experience, plagued by repetitive quests, a lackluster PvE loop, and technical hiccups like long queues and bugs. Fast forward to 2025, and New World: Aeternum feels like an entirely different game—in the best possible way. If you haven’t played in a while, it’s absolutely worth giving it another shot.

A Revamped Experience

The core of New World—its gorgeous world, action-based combat, and deep crafting system—remains, but nearly every aspect has been polished or overhauled. The leveling experience, once a slog of repetitive fetch quests, has been completely reimagined. The Brimstone Sands update and the Rise of the Angry Earth expansion introduced a more narrative-driven main storyline with cinematic cutscenes, voiced characters, and engaging lore that pulls you into the mystical island of Aeternum. Questing now feels purposeful, with varied objectives and a stronger sense of progression.

The introduction of mounts (horses, wolves, and lions) has addressed one of the biggest early complaints: excessive running. While the quests to unlock mounts can be a tad tedious, they drastically improve mobility, making exploration across Aeternum’s diverse landscapes a joy. The addition of new zones, like the visually stunning Ebonscale Reach and the reimagined First Light, adds fresh content and variety to the map.

Combat and Gameplay: Smoother and More Dynamic

Combat, always a highlight with its real-time, skill-based mechanics, has been refined further. New weapons like the Great Sword, Void Gauntlet, and Blunderbuss expand build diversity, while tweaks to weapon swapping and animations make fights feel more fluid. The classless system, where your abilities are tied to weapons and attributes, remains a refreshing departure from traditional MMOs, and the ability to respec easily encourages experimentation.

PvE content has seen significant upgrades. Expeditions (dungeons) are now more engaging, with challenging mechanics and unique enemies, especially in mutated versions. The Rise of the Angry Earth expansion added a new dungeon that, while not perfect, offers thrilling encounters. Enemy variety, a weak point at launch, has improved, though some reskinned mobs still linger. For solo players, the open world is more accessible, with activities like story quests and faction missions that don’t require grouping.

PvP, a cornerstone of New World, shines brighter than ever. The addition of 3v3 Arenas, a new open-world PvP zone, and a rewarding PvP track has reinvigorated competitive play. Territory control and faction wars feel more meaningful, with large-scale battles that foster community and strategy. Whether you’re a solo player or part of a company, there’s something for everyone.

Quality-of-Life and Endgame Improvements

Quality-of-life changes have been a game-changer. Fast travel is cheaper and more accessible, group finders make forming parties easier, and the expertise system for gear progression has been streamlined. The endgame, once a tedious grind, now offers a variety of activities: mutated expeditions, elite world bosses, and Outpost Rush (OPR) provide diverse ways to chase high gear scores. While some players still find the endgame loop repetitive, it’s a far cry from the barren state at launch.

The economy, once chaotic due to duping glitches and a lack of coin, is more stable, with a player-driven market that rewards dedicated crafters and gatherers. Speaking of crafting, it remains one of the most satisfying systems in any MMO, letting you gather, refine, and create everything from weapons to housing decorations.

A Vibrant World with Room to Grow

Aeternum’s atmosphere is unmatched, with a dynamic weather system, immersive sound design (thanks to composers like Ramin Djawadi), and breathtaking visuals powered by the Lumberyard engine. The game’s transition to a free-to-play model in 2023, with an optional premium battle pass and cosmetic-focused in-game shop, makes it more accessible, though some players grumble about the paid Rise of the Angry Earth expansion locking mounts and certain content.

There are still areas for improvement. Some dungeons could use more innovative boss mechanics, and the endgame can feel grindy for hardcore players. Performance issues persist for some, depending on hardware, and the lack of swimming remains a quirky immersion-breaker. However, Amazon’s commitment to regular updates and community feedback is evident, with each patch building on the last.

Is It Worth Playing in 2025?

For those who played at launch and left disappointed, New World: Aeternum is a revelation. The game has evolved from a promising but flawed MMO into a robust, immersive experience that rivals genre giants. Newcomers will find a beginner-friendly entry point with enough depth to keep them hooked for hundreds of hours. Returning players will be blown away by the improvements—faster leveling, richer storytelling, and a more rewarding endgame make it feel like a true second chance.

If you’re an MMO fan craving a vibrant world, satisfying crafting, and dynamic combat, New World deserves your attention. For just a one-time purchase (or free-to-play with some limitations), it’s a steal, especially with the Rise of the Angry Earth expansion adding significant value. I’ve sunk countless hours into Aeternum since day one, and I’m still excited to log in. Give it another shot—you won’t regret it.
